reviewText:
I feel like now that I'm at around 250 hours of gameplay (not including my time spent playing it offline on my laptop on the train) this review is in need of a rewrite. Here goes...

Dredmor is both infinitely awesome and infinitely cruel. So many things make it a great game, and there are so many ways that it will make you royally p'd off.

Gameplay
Basically Dredmor is a turn-based procedurally generated dungeon crawler (with the option for permadeath) in which you clear out a dungeon level by level until you hit the bottom and kill Lord Dredmor - a pretty simple premise and no back-story to speak of; but that's okay, this game is all about the gameplay, and the loot (oh so much loot).

Loot, Gear, and Crafting
I find, annoyingly, that this game punishes me for my compulsive hoarding of craftables because you will never be able to carry it all - but it will allow you to leave massive piles of loot lying about the place without ever taking them away from you, thus enticing you to ferry about every item you think you might possibly have a use for later... if you're into punishing yourself. Thankfully the game will let you speed up and slow down the animation rate by using the plus and minus keys (+/-) so you can make these little ferry trips less of a chore if you feel so inclined.
The craft system itself is pretty good. You get a base set of recipes and can find more stashed in bookcases scattered throughout the dungeon. You need to improve your skills to get better at crafting to make the higher level gear, however you'll often find that the best items are found throughout the dungeon rather than by crafting them. To balance this the game has an encrust system in which you can add extra elements to your basic items such as more damage to weapons or various resistances to armours (just be prepared for more compulsive hoarding to achieve the best results).
There are a number of shops randomly scattered throughout the dungeon, however they rarely provide the gear you really want and serve more as a place to sell your piles of unwanted loot just in case a shop later on has something you might want. At least it's nice to have piles and piles of gold coins.

Dying
The permadeath feature is very much welcome as stepping into a Monster Zoo (a special room absolutely packed with monsters) can be a daunting and exciting prospect when it could be the undoing of all your hard work; but don't worry, if that kind of thing annoys you, you can just turn permadeath off in the setup phase. When you do die, you will almost never feel tricked or like it was the outcome of bad game design; it is almost always because you did something stupid or weren't paying proper attention to where you were walking or to your health bar.

Skills
There are many skills you can specialise in and some of them are pretty weird - yep, you still have all the standard kind of skills like swordplay and archery, but Dredmor also includes some unique skills such as mathemagician, tourist, and communist. The best thing is that, regardless of what seven skills you pick, you are not locked into using certain types of equipment. If you find it, you can use it regardless of class or level. This means you can just play the character any way you want to, and this flexibility equates to fun. Loads of fun.

That Old-School Game Feel
Dredmor includes lots of references to other games and popular culture which are reminiscent of older games that didn't have to be so serious, and this really gives the game the extra shot of charm it needs to help you look past its flaws.

Graphics
Dredmor isn't 3D-rendered, it's illustrated, so you don't have to worry about graphic scaling, but none of your gear will appear on your player model aside from the type of weapon you swing when you actually perform your attack. This is a little disappointing at first, but Dredmor is so elegant in its design that this really doesn't matter; besides you still get to look at the illustrations of your gear in your inventory and character windows, which is enough.

Sound and Music
The sound effects are good and the music somehow never manages to wear thin. I imagine in years to come the soundtrack to Dredmor will inspire instant nostalgia in me, and when a game has that ability you know something is going right.

Achievements
I'm currently working my way through the long list of Dredmor achievements, and it's driving me INSANE. I initially thought oh yeah sure
date: these all seem reasonably obtainable..." WRONG. 250 hours I've been at it and still not there. One achievement refers to a skill that is no longer in the game and requires you to do some pretty fiddly changing of config files
recommended: and another one just has no way of progressing the counter whatsoever (to my knowledge

reviewText:
Dungeons of Dreamor is a dungeon crawling RPG with an interesting take on the turn based approach. By that, I mean that your actions count as turns. You don't go into a battle mode, the entire game works on turns. If you take a step, pick up an item, use an item, use a spell, use an attack, defend... all of these things count as a turn. So whenever you do something, every enemy gets to as well. This is also used in coodowns on abilities and regeneration of health and magic. Insead of waiting on a timer, you do actions to keep the game moving. It's great for pacing. Before you even start playing, you have some options you can set, and then you get to pick from a number of different abilities. So you're not restricted to a class, as in some other games like this. Instead, you just pick whatever abilities you want, which is fun for customization and replayability. As you level up, you can chose to level up those abilities as you see fit, but only one per level. The gameplay, aside from the turn system, is pretty standard. You walk around a huge dungeon, fighting enemies and looting the place. You can also craft a great number of things along the way, provided you have the materials, the tool used to craft it, and enough points in the required skill to make the item. This is where I start to have some issues.

See, you can pick your own skills. You can also level your own skills as you please. But sometimes you'll pick skills that don't cover the areas you need in order to make certain items. If you don't have that to level up, you simply cannot make those types of items. That can be annoying. It can also be annoying to have all the materials, the skills, and not the tool required to make the item. Although that can be remedied by finding one somewhere in the dungeon. My biggest complaint is that the inventory you have is a tad small. It makes you have to manage your items well, constantly craft items to use up materials (but that's not always so easy to do), or constantly backtrack to the shops to sell things. I guess you could leave stuff laying around but then it'd go to waste. Having a few more slots would help a lot. I guess it comes with the territory of looting. And with the skill complain, I suppose you just have to plan ahead and know what you can and can't do, which in turn will help you identify which items you do and do not need. Some of the skills in the begining don't explain what they do, choosing to have a joke description instead. This can be annoying to deal with and try to remember what they actually do later. Some of the drinkable and edible items you get aren't specific about what they do either. You might drink something or eat something that puts a debuff on you, hurts you, or even kills you! And the game is littered with traps. Some you can see, some you can't. Sometimes you can go around them, sometimes you need to walk over them to get to another spot. Sometimes you can disable them, sometimes that'll fail and they'll go off anyways. Imagine hitting a random trap that you couldn't even see, only to have THAT be the end of all your hard work. With permadeath on (as the default), it's quite maddening.

Still, this game is massive and... very difficult. I've sunk almost 20 hours into it as of right now and and never made it past the second floor. Am I bad? Maybe. But it's pretty easy to die from random stuff. I may have misread this but I think there's something like ten floors normally and fifteen with the expansions. So there's tons of stuff to do in this game. There's even tons of things I haven't even figured out yet! It's an amazing amount of content and playtime for what only costs you 5 bucks. Heck, toss in the extra buck for the DLC and get even more out of it like I did. It's very well worth the price tag and I'm really surprised it isn't going for more than that. It could definitely be a 10 or even 15 dollar game.

Dungeons of Dreadmor gets an 8/10 for being an immense dungeon crawler with an interesting take at a great price.

reviewText:
One of the most fun and addictive games I have ever found. Endless dungeon-crawling goodness with an enormous array of skills, tools, and combinations, a great sense of fun, and the ability to progress at your own speed. You can always roll up a new character and find something you hadn't seen before, or learn a new trick.

The game is a series of dungeons descending to an ultimate evil, with pocket dimensions, shops, and altars to various gods along the way. You create a character with a wide selection of skills in different trees (Archeology, Paranormal Investigation, Barbarian, to name only a few) which you can then level up as you progress. Along the way you fight strange and often hilarious monsters and collect materials to craft or sell. Strange combinations of these produce interesting results, mixing in teleportation, tunneling, invisibility, mind control, and many more!

The game is charming, the art is lovely, the creators are helpful and responsive, and the music is pleasant. Try it.

reviewText: The absolute best in rogue-like gaming.  Dungeons uses an excellent skill selection, character customization (not appearance), and many random elements to provide for a hundred different ways to play.  You can become a warrior with high damage and defense, a rogue with high counter-chance and dodging, or a mage with magical abilities.  Actually, if you wanted, you could become a combination of any of them, or even all three.  And the loot is plain awesome.  I normally pick up everything - be it an aged-steak or a magical robe - and take them to the wizard's pocket dimension to be sorted.  It's kind of a organized mess, with piles all along the walls and floor.  There are piles of mushrooms, gems, food, armor to be used in smithing/tinkering, tinkering parts, ingots for smithing, and stuff waiting to be sold.  And anything that isn't worth selling or keeping gets turned into lutifisk.  Yep, lutifisk.  You might be asking yourself Why I would be turning random junk into lutifisk?"

reviewText:
Warning, if you've never played this game, minor spoilers ahead. (Like, really minor, but spoilers nonetheless.)

This game is a unique combination of simple, easy, difficult, relaxing, laid-back, humorous, and just general old-fashioned fun. Holy crap it's fun. Basically you crawl your way through levels of the dungeon to get to the main bad-guy, accumulating a number of unique and silly items, skills, and badassery. Levelling up always feels good, and gaining a skill almost always has a noticeable affect on your combat.

Fair warning, you will die a lot. And if you're like me and love pain, you'll play on perma-death (which is optional). On about my fifth character, I was really getting into the swing of things. I had tons of items. I had a pocket dimension I could go to to dump unwanted detritus that might be useful in the future, and I'd just made it through the second floor (still haven't seen the third; the floors are fairly big and ooze with content and monsters). I was fairly powerful at this point, at least for the floor I was on, and easily laid waste to waves of monsters with the help of my zombies and clouds of poison that I conjured. So, feeling like a badass, I hopped over to my pocket dimension to drop off some loot, when I noticed that from said dimension I could also leap to other dimensions! Okay
recommended: so I did. Plowed through one small dimension, no sweat. So I go to another, run into two monsters, kill myself with my own poison cloud. It was my fault for not paying attention, but alllll the hard work, the several hours I'd put into his skills, levels, items. Gone!\n\nAt that point I said to myself, Okay
hoursPlayed: this is probably the point where going back to the first dungeon just becomes a tedious grind
voteText: and I won't want to play anymore." Well tonight I felt like trying again

reviewText:
Dungeons of Dredmor is an RPG set in a fantasy world. Play as a noble hero who must stop the demonic Lord Dredmora. The once very powerful, was finally defeated, stripped of his power, and then thrown into the underworld. Centuries later, after regenerating his powers, Lord Dredmor decides once again to destroy the human world.

Before the start of the game create your avatar. Producer gave up from the traditional choice of character classes. Instead, we assign our hero seven skills that come along with the progress in the game, we can develop.

Moving around randomly generated locations (mostly dungeons) kill hundreds of enemies, collect treasures and avoid traps. A variety of weapons includes swords, axes, and magic. During the game we are able to combine items and create them, such as healing potions or better weapons.

8/10

reviewText:
Dungeons of Dredmor is a graphical roguelike that parodies popular culture and roguelikes in general. It was released in 2011 by Gaslamp Games. Like most roguelikes it has procedurally-generated dungeons as well as a lot of monsters and items for the player to discover. Your task is to venture down into the unknown and vanquish the Dark Lord Dredmor.

There are three expansion packs available for Dredmor: Realm of the Diggle Gods, You Have To Name The Expansion Pack and Conquest of the Wizardlands. These bring more starting skills, monsters, levels and items into the base game and are all recommendable.

+Very replayable.
+Lots of humorous references.
+Challenging, especially on hardest difficulties.
+A huge selection of starting skills.
+An easy-to-use interface.

-Some builds are very overpowered and some can be practically impossible to win with.
-Tends to slow down when there are many enemies and items on the screen at once.
-One Steam achievement is bugged and one is practically impossible to get.

And remember:

LUTEFISK FOR THE LUTEFISK GOD!
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Dungeons of Dredmore is a great rogue-like RPG, playing both as an homage and parody to the hack 'n' slash and roleplaying games of old.  What makes this game stand out most is the artistic style and the humor of the game itself, being sure to take itself just seriously enough to remain a very solid game.  Also worth mention is the music within the game, composed by Matthew Steele.  If you are a lover of the rogue-like genre, this game is a great deal at less than $5 (U.S.)

reviewText:
Dungeons of Dredmor is a pretty fun look at the old roguelike genre, and was a great romp down memory lane. While the graphics are simple, as is the gameplay, a simple interface masks a surprisingly deep customization and talent system. The synergy between different skills will have you experimenting with builds for DAYS. The addition and seamless integration of Steam Workshop was nothing short of brilliant, and when you feel like you've seen everything in Dungeons of Dredmor, provides HOURS of extra enjoyment.

Good: Solid gameplay, fun visual aesthetic, good music. Deep and complex customization presented in a brilliantly accesible way.

Bad: Some skills are just too good. Whenever there's a skill that me and ALL my friends separately came to the conclusion that it MUST be in your build, things need a little tinkering.

Ugly: Not much.

Possibly the worst thing I can say about DoD is that the era of the traditional rogue formula is definitely showing its age. The procedure of I move

reviewText:
ARGH THIS GAME IS SO GOOD
It's a fun little rogue-like (and a genuine rogue-like this time,) where every runthrough is different and fun in its own way. You can try-hard it or mash the random button when choosing your character's skills at start and still have a pretty good time. The game is simple and streamlined where it needs to be and more complex where it should be. Grab the DLC too, and pick up some small mods that don't interfere with the core experience too much, and you've got yourself a fun experience that you won't regret. I'm willing to say this is the best *real* rogue-like (and not just a game with rogue-like elements; Binding of Isaac for example) on Steam.

I highly recommend going in on the highest difficulty setting with hardcore mode on.

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yG_Sbada8BQ

Dungeons of Dredmor: An old schoolish, dungeon crawling, loot grabbing, Diggle killing, grid based, rogue-like indie game from Gaslamp Games.

Dungeons of Dredmor is a really simple and challenging game, when starting a new game you are first asked to choose between difficulties, permanent death or not and smaller dungeons with the same number of enemies and, if you have the DLC an additional 15 levels to go through. You will not be hurting for things to see and do in Dungeons of Dredmor also, if anyone has gotten 100% on it you are truly one of a kind. Next you are greeted with picking skills, you can choose up to 7 skills from a list of 50 different skills, all offering unique abilities and play styles, and once you've chosen between such skills as Emomancy, Killer Vegan and Bankster you choose male or female and enter the dungeons!

The story behind this game is that the evil lich Dredmor was imprisoned beneath the world for being a meanie but, has slowly eroded away his bonds and you are asked to enter into his prison (or dungeon) and stop him!...again! Its dirt simple but, hey it works well and the dungeons are no joke.

The game is grid based and combat is turned based, you can click or use the keyboard to move, upon entering combat you trade shots with your foe, (or take turns), the challenge of Dredmor is in how you build your character and, a little bit of luck with finding powerful items and shrines but, mostly in how you build your character. Although there are many skills to pick from some are better suited for dungeoneering than others, some only work better with other skills and there are some that are must haves, make no mistake there are ideal builds for this game.

Items come in to play a little bit, especially food and healing items but, the crafting system in Dredmor is deep, there is a lot to craft and I haven't personally seen it but, what I have seen is almost every item in the game being craft-able. There are also skills associated with crafting, so you can build your character around any of the crafts if you so choose (such as being a clockwork, steam-punk knight) and, crafting things is as simple as having the crafting kit and using it with the correct items and there are a TON of items to craft.

The graphics are also nice with this mix of hand painted/ comic look style, the game also runs as smooth as butter and, looks so simple you should be able to run it on just about anything so it's a great game for laptops. My only complaint about the graphics is more of a personal desire, the game shows you all these really neat hand-drawn items that look totally badass however, it never shows on your character; your character always will have the same frilly Guybrush Threepwood outfit regardless of the badass armor and traffic cone you have equipped, that kind of detail would have been greatly appreciated.

Music in the game is excellent, with lots of organ, piano and strings, giving a sort of melancholy tune alongside some quirky upbeat tunes. The tracks tend to repeat if you linger on a floor too long so that may be a downside depending on how much you like it and, the music is what you'll listen to the majority of the games (in fact it often overpowers the other sounds of the game) so it’s a good thing it’s an awesome soundtrack.

Dungeons of Dredmor is funny and challenging, a great game to play anywhere and caters to a lot of playstyles, it’s a solid experience and gives you a huge amount of content to enjoy for a cheap price of $4.99 USD. For $6.99 USD you can get the complete set which I honestly suggest because it’s a great deal for the amount of added content you get even if you don’t end up seeing all of it. If you want a challenge, or a never ending rogue-like game, enter the Dungeons of Dredmor!

TL/DR; Dungeons of Dredmor is a rogue-like dungeon crawler with a HUGE amount of content for $4.99 USD, it’s got humor, charm and challenge, with plenty to do and replay ability to the Nth degree. It’s really cheap for what you get, Gaslamp Games certainly is giving you bang for your buck, honestly, if you don’t own the game, consider getting the full package for $6.99 USD, it’s just a few extra bucks and well worth it, plus the DLC by itself is $5.98 USD on its own so don’t waste your money unnecessarily! Check it out and support these guys so we can get more greatness in the future!

-Double Thumbs up from Royial

reviewerDisplayName: And then John was a zombie.
reviewText:
This game has been netted as one of my personal favorite roguelikes. A big fan of Gaslamp and their crew - I'm stoked to have been part of a lot of beta testing for the content of this game and even to where an achievement that I suggested on the forums has been added in! :D

Now. This game sets up the limits of...weird. And the DLC has only improved it. The crafting system is large and well varied, the Wizard Keys and finding graffitti scrawled on the walls with codes to new levels, all the loot you can shake a stick at, in-game vending machines selling you everything from baseballs to ground meat and nukes and Root Of T'char.

The greatest thing about this game is how varied the outcomes can be. You have the choices of 6 different talent trees out of 15+ ones and none are right" OR "wrong." The game gives you the freedom to play as you please and the Save-Exit function is a godsend when you start delving and you feel tired. Levelling up and playing is turn based and the enemies move as you move.

Overall: I have so much fun with this game that I've yet to finish ONE game. 70+ hours on and offline with this game and every time there's that itch to re-roll a character and try a new combination JUST BECAUSE the skill trees augment and vary your gameplay so much!

reviewText:
An excellent game, providing replay value as well as challenge. If you like rogue-like games, this is a good one to invest in.

The character choices are many, allowing for any number of gameplay styles and also allowing for an even greater amount of variety, which is fantastic. The skill tree system is straight-forward and nicely balanced, which is lovely as well.

It's comedic in many parts, from the absolutely absurd names it randomly generates, to the moderately silly introduction, to the many, many references to a whole bunch of different things - like Morrowind and Bioshock, to name a few.

If I had to complain about anything, I'd say that I'd like to see more permanent unlockables, kind of like in The Binding of Isaac, where you can unlock items to find in later runs by achieving certain landmarks.

Even at that, however, the game is more than satisfying.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game has the best and most creative class creation system I've ever seen.

You mix and match your skills, all skills being available to any character, and, because no classes, no class restrictions.

You can run, for instance, a heavy-armor mace-spec necromancer vampire mage.  Or a berserker who deals elemental damage and huge crits and can craft his own gear.  Or a stealthy archaeologist banker.

For that alone, and the new-piece-of-gum delight of running into the dungeons again with a new skill group, this game is worth the $5 it costs to pick it up.

2600+ Steam players couldn't be wrong.

reviewText:
Incredibly challenging turn based roguelike with tongue-in-cheek humor. There's a complicated crafting system, randomly generated dungeons, a customizable skill tree, and... well that's about it. It's very good to entertain you when you're bored, but don't expect to really get anywhere.

Storyline: 1/10 - As far as I can tell, there isn't one.
Graphics: 3/10 - Not much effort was put in to them, but not much effort was needed.
Sound: 2/10 - Splat and squish effects recorded in someone's bathroom.
Gameplay: 7/10 - You don't play for anything else here. This game is ALL about the gameplay, and it's fantastic at it.

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yG_Sbada8BQ

Dungeons of Dredmor: An old schoolish, dungeon crawling, loot grabbing, Diggle killing, grid based, rogue-like indie game from Gaslamp Games.

Dungeons of Dredmor is a really simple and challenging game, when starting a new game you are first asked to choose between difficulties, permanent death or not and smaller dungeons with the same number of enemies and, if you have the DLC an additional 15 levels to go through. You will not be hurting for things to see and do in Dungeons of Dredmor also, if anyone has gotten 100% on it you are truly one of a kind. Next you are greeted with picking skills, you can choose up to 7 skills from a list of 50 different skills, all offering unique abilities and play styles, and once you've chosen between such skills as Emomancy, Killer Vegan and Bankster you choose male or female and enter the dungeons!

The story behind this game is that the evil lich Dredmor was imprisoned beneath the world for being a meanie but, has slowly eroded away his bonds and you are asked to enter into his prison (or dungeon) and stop him!...again! Its dirt simple but, hey it works well and the dungeons are no joke.

The game is grid based and combat is turned based, you can click or use the keyboard to move, upon entering combat you trade shots with your foe, (or take turns), the challenge of Dredmor is in how you build your character and, a little bit of luck with finding powerful items and shrines but, mostly in how you build your character. Although there are many skills to pick from some are better suited for dungeoneering than others, some only work better with other skills and there are some that are must haves, make no mistake there are ideal builds for this game.

Items come in to play a little bit, especially food and healing items but, the crafting system in Dredmor is deep, there is a lot to craft and I haven't personally seen it but, what I have seen is almost every item in the game being craft-able. There are also skills associated with crafting, so you can build your character around any of the crafts if you so choose (such as being a clockwork, steam-punk knight) and, crafting things is as simple as having the crafting kit and using it with the correct items and there are a TON of items to craft.

The graphics are also nice with this mix of hand painted/ comic look style, the game also runs as smooth as butter and, looks so simple you should be able to run it on just about anything so it's a great game for laptops. My only complaint about the graphics is more of a personal desire, the game shows you all these really neat hand-drawn items that look totally badass however, it never shows on your character; your character always will have the same frilly Guybrush Threepwood outfit regardless of the badass armor and traffic cone you have equipped, that kind of detail would have been greatly appreciated.

Music in the game is excellent, with lots of organ, piano and strings, giving a sort of melancholy tune alongside some quirky upbeat tunes. The tracks tend to repeat if you linger on a floor too long so that may be a downside depending on how much you like it and, the music is what you'll listen to the majority of the games (in fact it often overpowers the other sounds of the game) so it’s a good thing it’s an awesome soundtrack.

Dungeons of Dredmor is funny and challenging, a great game to play anywhere and caters to a lot of playstyles, it’s a solid experience and gives you a huge amount of content to enjoy for a cheap price of $4.99 USD. For $6.99 USD you can get the complete set which I honestly suggest because it’s a great deal for the amount of added content you get even if you don’t end up seeing all of it. If you want a challenge, or a never ending rogue-like game, enter the Dungeons of Dredmor!

TL/DR; Dungeons of Dredmor is a rogue-like dungeon crawler with a HUGE amount of content for $4.99 USD, it’s got humor, charm and challenge, with plenty to do and replay ability to the Nth degree. It’s really cheap for what you get, Gaslamp Games certainly is giving you bang for your buck, honestly, if you don’t own the game, consider getting the full package for $6.99 USD, it’s just a few extra bucks and well worth it, plus the DLC by itself is $5.98 USD on its own so don’t waste your money unnecessarily! Check it out and support these guys so we can get more greatness in the future!

-Double Thumbs up from Royial

reviewText: Incredible game with an amazing sense of humor, more games should aspire to be like Dungeons of Dredmor. The fun never ends thanks to the games difficult design and many mods from the workshop, Gaslamp games deserves way more than what it has gotten from this game. Considered a casual rouge-like, is probably the toughest on the steam market. I have only beaten the default game twice in all my hours playing, and have yet to defeat the final boss on the Diggle realms DLC (All the DLC is worth buying since its dirt cheap and adds a lot to the game).  You can sit down and play this game or go on and off on a run, personally I like to play this while I listen to a podcast. BUY THIS GAME.

reviewText:
An excellent game, providing replay value as well as challenge. If you like rogue-like games, this is a good one to invest in.

The character choices are many, allowing for any number of gameplay styles and also allowing for an even greater amount of variety, which is fantastic. The skill tree system is straight-forward and nicely balanced, which is lovely as well.

It's comedic in many parts, from the absolutely absurd names it randomly generates, to the moderately silly introduction, to the many, many references to a whole bunch of different things - like Morrowind and Bioshock, to name a few.

If I had to complain about anything, I'd say that I'd like to see more permanent unlockables, kind of like in The Binding of Isaac, where you can unlock items to find in later runs by achieving certain landmarks.

Even at that, however, the game is more than satisfying.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game has the best and most creative class creation system I've ever seen.

You mix and match your skills, all skills being available to any character, and, because no classes, no class restrictions.

You can run, for instance, a heavy-armor mace-spec necromancer vampire mage.  Or a berserker who deals elemental damage and huge crits and can craft his own gear.  Or a stealthy archaeologist banker.

For that alone, and the new-piece-of-gum delight of running into the dungeons again with a new skill group, this game is worth the $5 it costs to pick it up.

2600+ Steam players couldn't be wrong.

reviewText:
Dungeons of Dredmor is a pretty fun look at the old roguelike genre, and was a great romp down memory lane. While the graphics are simple, as is the gameplay, a simple interface masks a surprisingly deep customization and talent system. The synergy between different skills will have you experimenting with builds for DAYS. The addition and seamless integration of Steam Workshop was nothing short of brilliant, and when you feel like you've seen everything in Dungeons of Dredmor, provides HOURS of extra enjoyment.

Good: Solid gameplay, fun visual aesthetic, good music. Deep and complex customization presented in a brilliantly accesible way.

Bad: Some skills are just too good. Whenever there's a skill that me and ALL my friends separately came to the conclusion that it MUST be in your build, things need a little tinkering.

Ugly: Not much.

Possibly the worst thing I can say about DoD is that the era of the traditional rogue formula is definitely showing its age. The procedure of I move
recommended: then I move" is showing its age as a design process. Dungeons of Dredmor could be that last
hoursPlayed: best look at a wonderful genre
voteText: and I enjoyed the hell out of it
helpfulPercent: but I think it will be the last true rogue I play. It's time to see what the words "rogue like" can do attached to other formats of gameplay."
commentsCount: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
ARGH THIS GAME IS SO GOOD
It's a fun little rogue-like (and a genuine rogue-like this time,) where every runthrough is different and fun in its own way. You can try-hard it or mash the random button when choosing your character's skills at start and still have a pretty good time. The game is simple and streamlined where it needs to be and more complex where it should be. Grab the DLC too, and pick up some small mods that don't interfere with the core experience too much, and you've got yourself a fun experience that you won't regret. I'm willing to say this is the best *real* rogue-like (and not just a game with rogue-like elements; Binding of Isaac for example) on Steam.

I highly recommend going in on the highest difficulty setting with hardcore mode on.

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yG_Sbada8BQ

Dungeons of Dredmor: An old schoolish, dungeon crawling, loot grabbing, Diggle killing, grid based, rogue-like indie game from Gaslamp Games.

Dungeons of Dredmor is a really simple and challenging game, when starting a new game you are first asked to choose between difficulties, permanent death or not and smaller dungeons with the same number of enemies and, if you have the DLC an additional 15 levels to go through. You will not be hurting for things to see and do in Dungeons of Dredmor also, if anyone has gotten 100% on it you are truly one of a kind. Next you are greeted with picking skills, you can choose up to 7 skills from a list of 50 different skills, all offering unique abilities and play styles, and once you've chosen between such skills as Emomancy, Killer Vegan and Bankster you choose male or female and enter the dungeons!

The story behind this game is that the evil lich Dredmor was imprisoned beneath the world for being a meanie but, has slowly eroded away his bonds and you are asked to enter into his prison (or dungeon) and stop him!...again! Its dirt simple but, hey it works well and the dungeons are no joke.

The game is grid based and combat is turned based, you can click or use the keyboard to move, upon entering combat you trade shots with your foe, (or take turns), the challenge of Dredmor is in how you build your character and, a little bit of luck with finding powerful items and shrines but, mostly in how you build your character. Although there are many skills to pick from some are better suited for dungeoneering than others, some only work better with other skills and there are some that are must haves, make no mistake there are ideal builds for this game.

Items come in to play a little bit, especially food and healing items but, the crafting system in Dredmor is deep, there is a lot to craft and I haven't personally seen it but, what I have seen is almost every item in the game being craft-able. There are also skills associated with crafting, so you can build your character around any of the crafts if you so choose (such as being a clockwork, steam-punk knight) and, crafting things is as simple as having the crafting kit and using it with the correct items and there are a TON of items to craft.

The graphics are also nice with this mix of hand painted/ comic look style, the game also runs as smooth as butter and, looks so simple you should be able to run it on just about anything so it's a great game for laptops. My only complaint about the graphics is more of a personal desire, the game shows you all these really neat hand-drawn items that look totally badass however, it never shows on your character; your character always will have the same frilly Guybrush Threepwood outfit regardless of the badass armor and traffic cone you have equipped, that kind of detail would have been greatly appreciated.

Music in the game is excellent, with lots of organ, piano and strings, giving a sort of melancholy tune alongside some quirky upbeat tunes. The tracks tend to repeat if you linger on a floor too long so that may be a downside depending on how much you like it and, the music is what you'll listen to the majority of the games (in fact it often overpowers the other sounds of the game) so it’s a good thing it’s an awesome soundtrack.

Dungeons of Dredmor is funny and challenging, a great game to play anywhere and caters to a lot of playstyles, it’s a solid experience and gives you a huge amount of content to enjoy for a cheap price of $4.99 USD. For $6.99 USD you can get the complete set which I honestly suggest because it’s a great deal for the amount of added content you get even if you don’t end up seeing all of it. If you want a challenge, or a never ending rogue-like game, enter the Dungeons of Dredmor!

TL/DR; Dungeons of Dredmor is a rogue-like dungeon crawler with a HUGE amount of content for $4.99 USD, it’s got humor, charm and challenge, with plenty to do and replay ability to the Nth degree. It’s really cheap for what you get, Gaslamp Games certainly is giving you bang for your buck, honestly, if you don’t own the game, consider getting the full package for $6.99 USD, it’s just a few extra bucks and well worth it, plus the DLC by itself is $5.98 USD on its own so don’t waste your money unnecessarily! Check it out and support these guys so we can get more greatness in the future!

-Double Thumbs up from Royial

Video Reviews: youtube.com/RoyialNetwork

reviewText:
Incredibly challenging turn based roguelike with tongue-in-cheek humor. There's a complicated crafting system, randomly generated dungeons, a customizable skill tree, and... well that's about it. It's very good to entertain you when you're bored, but don't expect to really get anywhere.

Storyline: 1/10 - As far as I can tell, there isn't one.
Graphics: 3/10 - Not much effort was put in to them, but not much effort was needed.
Sound: 2/10 - Splat and squish effects recorded in someone's bathroom.
Gameplay: 7/10 - You don't play for anything else here. This game is ALL about the gameplay, and it's fantastic at it.

reviewText: Missing alot of strategy elements and decisions. Very simplified. If feels like the Munchkin version  of what was supposed to be a roguelike. There is a difference between random for the sake of random and an engine designed to be random but with plenty of modifiers and things that affect outcomes and many solutions for every problem. When you die rarely is it because of an element of the game that you didnt understand properly or something that could have been stopped or modified if you had taken the proper steps to prevent it. If you want a good true roguelike from the steam store buy Tales of Maj'eyal or Vulture for nethack(nethack is free so are most of the tile sets, but vulture has a GUI and mouse controls so its easier to play without having to remember the 40-60 commands for nethack). The Nethack engine is by far the most in depth classic roguelike engine on steam even though its over 20 years old. Or get Wazhack for a different style of rogue

reviewText:
Dungeons of Dredmor is a roguelike. For those of us who are not elite(ist) gamers, just think of it as a hard hack-and-slash game with procedurally generated content and very real risk of permanent death which forces you to start over (a little wiser each time)

My initial impression of this game was a very positive one. It's very easy to get into, has a lot of skills to choose from for character creation (implying lots of replayability, but I was wrong) and it covers everything with a layer of clever tongue-in-cheek humor (like witty pop culture references? this game has lots!)

However after playing this game on a netbook for over 80 hours, properly experiencing it in all its glory, I stand corrected enough to say that I would not recommend this game to someone else looking to derive some fun out of their play sessions, unless their entertainment consists in dying over and over unfairly...case in which I probably still wouldn't recommend this game because it simply isn't that good all things considered.

First off, a major technical issue. This game is built poorly, seemingly by dwarven plasticsmiths (those ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s) It's a little 2D game with sprites that have 2 animations each. Still it actively takes 600MB of RAM, reserving even more than that. On my 2GB RAM netbook I can forget running this and a browser at the same time.

Shame, because it looks like exactly the type of game to be played on a netbook/tablet, and not on a proper desktop configuration like the game demands. It also personally annoys me as this seems to be a problem with more and more lazy pixel-style indie games: games that look like they were made 20 years ago demand 4GB RAM and 1GB VRAM. What the hell?

Onto the gameplay itself. It's balls hard. Not in a good way as it seemed on first glance. It's unfairly and frustratingly hard. It's unfair because while you have an ample amount of skills to choose from, only a few are actually effective (give you a high likelyhood of winning the game) while others are downright useless. The same goes for weapons (don't use crossbows unless you like taking 4x longer than a character with his bare hands to win the game). This wouldn't be so bad, as every such game has some strategies that work better than others, but this game in particular is very stingy with its descriptions of mechanics. Without reading a guide, you will frequently encounter weapons and abilities whose actual effects are very underwhelming compared to what their descriptions would have you believe. You pretty much have to read a guide before diving into the game, or you'll frequently wonder what does THAT mean" when finding
recommended: an artifact or another with a typical description like "The honorable poodles - it is studded with cheese crust and decorated with high quality tin"\n\nOnce that's out of the way
hoursPlayed: and you finally have a good understanding of the game mechanics that let you create an effective character with a fair chance of winning...you will run into another problem. Basically
voteText: once you figure out how to not die
helpfulPercent: everything all the way up until the final boss becomes one relatively simple
votesTotal: long-winded repetitive grind. And the final boss? FUBAR
votesFunny: because even many good builds won't scratch that guy (hints: Magical Law
commentsCount: Burglary
column16: Crossbow
column17: crafting/encrusting in general). A situation in which 99% of the game play is mindless faceroll
column18: and that 1% (final boss) has the shot of taking it all away because of RNG is not fun (again
column19: unless you're a difficulty fetishist). I also have to ask myself why they even made the game with 51 skills to choose from when less than 15 of those are actually going to let you win the game.\n\nCould it be that in spite of first impressions
column20: this is not that good of a game?"

reviewText:
This game was recommended to me by one of my friends. He absolutely rants and raves about how much fun he has with it... I'm not sure that we should be friends anymore. This game is extremely boring. The enemies are simple recolorings, the combat is not challenging other than trying to stay awake, and the levels are bland.

The humor in the game is slightly funny at first... But this is not enough to keep anyone interested on this alone. The battle mechanics are repetitive and the only real strategy is to funnel the enemies into a hallway where they can't attack more than 1 or 2 at a time and hack away. The graphics are HORRIBLE. A few floors in the background/floor/wall/everything looks like a gravel driveway with vomit mixed in.

At some point, I stopped playing the game, and just started seeing how many characters I could create with some form of eyebrow" in their name...

And then I shelved it....  Overall
date: I'd say if you've never played a top down turn based roguelike
recommended: or if you want a reason to never play  another top down turn based roguelike
hoursPlayed: maybe pick this up when it's on sale. If you want a game that will keep you interested for more than half an hour without feeling like repeatedly clicking on an icon in windows 3.0

reviewText:
I've been playing turn-based RPG rogue-likes since Nethack and Zangband.  This game does alot of interesting things with the procedurally generated dungeons. By the time I got to character level 10 on dungeon level 5 I was so incredibly bored with the gameplay that I accidentally didnt watch my health bar and died.

The difference between my experience with this game and others is that when I accidentally died I was glad that I didn't have to play any more because it was so incredibly boring.

If you like this game, just go download Nethack or Zangband for free. They dont have the graphical tiles but the gameplay is ten times better.

reviewText: A great entry level roguelike with a good sense of humour. Just as most of the games of this genre, it's fun as long as you're striving for survival. Once you find a self-sustaining skill build, get lucky with items AND don't do any mistakes, it becomes easy and kinda repetitive, but those are circumstances some players might never experience and therefore they could enjoy the game even more. I only wish monster zoos were either implemented differently or removed from the game. Other than that and some skill explanations being cryptic at times, it's a really good, polished game that I highly recommend.

reviewText: It's a roguelike game....OK let's be more specific: Dungeons of Dredmor, I believe, is a perfect gateway into the roguelike genre, which is normally populated by games that are massively complex and nearly impenetratable to normal gamers, since those mainly used minimal graphics, user interface mostly designed for machines that are 20 years old or more and massive complexity which several games don't bother supplying adequate tutorials (and lots of newer roguelikes still opt to follow that tradition, though recent trends are going against that). Dredmor, though, evades all the above shortcomings pretty well, with good graphics, humor and good introduction to the game combined with complexity that is not too deep but is still deep enough.\n\nAnd after this maybe you want to try more roguelike games!

reviewText:
I never thought i'd like a Rogue game, but i do, and it's this one.

I mostly play games where i can level up and save and load when i have to, i get stressed and depressed and angry when dying hardcore-mode. But DoD is fun!
Lives can stretch for a long time and there are several skills to explore and combine and they are all cool.

Graphics and music is mediocre, but that doesn't matter. The more you play the more you learn on what to do and more importantly what NOT to do. But read a wiki after a game or two to learn more is my advice.

Sure, i can recommend this if you like RPG and a challenge.

reviewText: Very well-written dungeon crawler. The dev obviously has a good sense of humor and put together a pretty interesting game. No fancy graphics or elaborate quests/puzzles, but entertaining nonetheless. If you like the type of game that makes fun of itself, then this is for you. Some of the skills/classes are a bit...overpowered...while others are practically useless, but they still offer a ton of replayability and I'm sure that there are lots of build combinations I haven't even come across yet. I'd pick it up on sale for sure.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
If you long for the old days of pixel graphics and dungeoneering or just like turnbased, really entertaining RPGs in general, you should definitely check this one out. It's intended to play like a classic Roguelike, but you can also turn off permadeath and just have fun with it as a normal RPG.

The selfaware humour, the different character builds and the random dungeons will keep you entertained for quite a while! As of this writing, the game still has a couple of bugs that can be quite a nuisance, but the developers are very active and responsive about issues, so that's also a plus. The game also has very good mod support and a healthy community providing new content.

For what little money this costs, you get quite a lot of value. Worth a look for sure!

reviewText: This game will reel you in to play hours and hundreds of hours of exploring vast dungeons, learning various skills and slaughtering numerous monsters. It is probably as user friendly as a roguelike game can get. You will enjoy this game if you like oldschool RPGs, wacky sense of humor and crossing your fingers in hopes of getting a nice sword out of a smashed open chest.\n\nОчень няшный рогалик с кучей лута, скиллов, циферок, буковок и безумства. Великолепная поглощалка времени и неплохая временная замена той большой игре которая выйдет где-нибудь через сколько-нибудь времени.

reviewText: One of the best rougelikes I've ever played. If you are new to rougelikes, you will have a real easy time playing this game since it has a mouse interface. The game even has a sense of humor, which is rare for rougelikes. There are a lot of references in the game also, but these things don't make the game any easier if you think it does. I still can't beat the game even though my experience with the rougelike genre. So, the bottom line is, expect to die. A lot. It's a fun and humoruos game and a hard one at that. I recommend it highly.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
When I started playing this game, I liked it, but the more I played the more I realized how boring and uninteresting it is. First of all, there are many technical problems with the engine. Crashes (with an achievement), bugs and input lag are always part of the experience. I never bothered with the non-permadeath mode but If you play this mode, the game is completely broken due to crashes corrupting the save file.

The humor in Dungeons of Dredmor is something most people seem to be in love with but I found it to be uninspired, unoriginal and not funny in any way. The more hours I spent playing, the less patience I had with the game's poor performance and input lag. These two issues are simply awful and unbearable after a while. Worst of all is the crafting and lack of a decent enough inventory system. If you make a character build focused on crafting, you will be in for the most frustrating, annoying, cumbersome experience in any crafting related game. It's so poorly implemented and backwards that once you go through the troubles of attempting to keep ingredients/items, organize them and finally begin crafting, you will never want to craft another item in this game again. The negative combination of the awful inventory system and the hideous crafting system is enough to quit playing and never go back to Dungeons of Dredmor again. Sure, the game could certainly be played using other builds and you don't have to craft anything to beat it, but the horrendous inventory system is still there and there is no way of making it less painful to organize, keep and use items. Dungeons of Dredmor could have been so much better if the developers spent more time polishing and tweaking many of the major issues the game has.

Dungeons of Dredmor is mediocre.

reviewText:
Pros:
- It's a good intro to Rogelikes
- It's polished, the theme is consistent and I experienced no bugs

Cons:
- Repetitive, each level has the same mobs, just a different color
- There is little to no strategy in combat.
- While I thought the crafting was going to be promising, by the time you get enough materials, you'll have found half a dozen of the item you want to craft
- The only challenge in this game is  the final boss, which after such cake-walk of a game will likely cause you to rage-quit after two-shotting you

I played through this game with very minimal difficulty and I can say that if you're a Rogelike fan who hasn't played this, skip it. It you haven't played a Rogelike before and want to take baby steps into the genre, this game might be for you. Word of warning, it's very repetitive.

reviewText:
It's slow-paced, brutally difficult, and not very pretty.

And I love it.

This is a throw-back to Castle of the Winds, NetHack, and any other rogue-like you can think of. This will not be a game that you're on the edge of your seat playing. It requires much more methodical planning and strategy. With the combinations of skills you can use, it is incredibly deep. Some combinations of skills make the game borderline impossible, but once you get your feet wet, you'll have a good idea of which skills work with which other skills.

Don't forget that permadeath is the default, so if you don't want your save files to be deleted when you die, make sure to turn that feature off.

I love this style of game, so this gets a 9/10 from me. If you like this genre, you can easily sink 200 hours into this game and still not see everything.

reviewText: A strange but potent combination of humor and dying, both of them in immense quantities. DoD is a whimsical, sometimes downright sadistic game, throwing you into startling deathtraps at a moment's notice, while perpetually referencing and parodying roguelike genre conventions in most wacky, even disturbing ways. DoD does all this while being remarkably fun and addictive. It's superfluous mentioning replay value in here as it is staple of the genre.

so this is great game with overhelmingly great (95%)  reviews ?

at first glance it is good game. catchy, interesting, relatively easy to play. lots of jokes, and it is good.
but

3) after easy run without any problems you met lord dredmor and guess what? he can instakill you. after 10hour, that is SERIOUS design flaw.
4) there are some UI elements which are just annoying. for example I can't use autoloot, because at my storage It will pick all. I dont feel like enagling and disabling it all the time, so I pick all by hand. and it sucks.
or if I want to open menu (to change autoloot or settings) I press ESC and it close inventory. press it again, and it closes character screen. press third time and we have menu! and now I have to open character screen and inventory again. yes it is minor thing. it is also stupid and anoying. and there are more...


at all, I think this is GOOD game. problem is, that it is in 60-70% good. absolutely not 95% as suggested by steam reviews.
that is why I vote NO.  It has so many YES votes, it has become seriously misleading.

VERDICT: if you like games like this and want to try another, buy it !
but there are some indie / rouge games that I think are better.

reviewText:
Long ago, the Dark Lord Dredmor was bound in the darkest dungeons beneath the earth by great and mighty heroes. Centuries later, the magical bonds that hold him in place are loosening and his power grows ever stronger. The land cries out for a new hero, a powerful warrior or a mystic wizard like those spoken of in the prophecies of yore.

What they have, unfortunately, is you...

Step into the Dungeons of Dredmor! Embrace your destiny! Face evil of the likes the world has never known - the terrifying Swarmies, the undulating Thrusties, and the adoreable nest-building Diggles. Worship Inconsequentia, the Goddess of Pointless Sidequests, or try your luck as a devotee of the nameless Lutefisk God. Cast powerful magic learned from the dark business warlocks of the school of Necronomiconomics, or summon the Viking Runes of your ancestors to blast your foes with thunder and lightning! Discover the power that can be had by wielding a bizarre armament of devastating weaponry such as the Interdimensional Axe, the Plastic Ring, and the Invisible Shield (if you can remember where you left it). Wield shoes decorated by the Dwarven Glittersmiths, all of whom have now committed suicide because of their shame, and embrace the joys of destroying giant moustache-wielding brick demons with a mace decorated with tawdry, delicious bacon.

While you’re at it, be prepared to die. A lot. In hideous, screaming pain that makes you throw your keyboard out the window.

The Dungeons of Dredmor await. Are you ready for them?
voteText: 8 of 22 people (36%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Not recommending it may seem a bit harsh. The game is funny, the graphics nice for the genre, there's plenty of depth and it is original in many ways. For the price I paid (part of a Humble Bundle) and the £3.49 it is on Steam, it is very, very good value.

However it is flawed. It is so slow to play and there's so much repetition of doing the same thing i.e. fighting - which is a problem common to many turn-based roguelikes but overcome by most with instantaneous response enabling quite large battles to be resolved quickly. Sadly this is not the case with Dredmor, making the early levels quite laborious on repeat play throughs. Since it is a permadeath game, I soon tired of trudging my way through the early levels and soon put the game into my archives.

You won't be wasting your money buying Dungeons of Dredmor, but if you want a game that will draw you in and keep you coming back for more, I'd be surprised if you found it here.

reviewText: Dungeons of Dredmor is not a bad game; instead, it's an amusing, well-intentioned game that lacks the polish and ease of play which we have come to expect from games.  The play style harkens back to the earliest dungeon crawlers, featuring randomly generated dungeons, punishing combat, and a wealth of customization.  It's charm lies in the witty, inane humor sprinked in everything; my personal favorite joke were the shrines littering the dungeon, where you could pray to the goddess of side-quests, and receive a random task.  I swear, it's much funnier than my lame description implies.  Nonetheless, it's difficult to reccomend for you to buy the game, as the gameplay is extremely clunky, especially item and spell management.  For items, you must click and drag every single thing in the game.  That means that when you come across a trove of 9 pieces of Lutefisk, you either have to click and drag 8 times, or get lazy and leave them sitting there.  It's simply frustrating.  Additionally, stats and related systems are poorly, if at all, explained.  It becomes a burdon to try to compare one piece of armor against another.  All-in-all, Dungeons of Dredmor is an entertaining series of jokes, that lacks the polishing necessary for today's game market.

reviewText:
Has an interesting graphical style, but really falls short, if you're a roguelike fan. No diagonal movement? Can't attack enemies simply by moving 'into' them? A not-quite-top-down perspective that causes walls to obscure the row above them? Animated movement you can't disable or speed up (a big one for roguelike 'vets' that don't want superfluous 'sparkle' that slows them down)?

Sorry, can't recommend this. Even Hack, Slash, Loot, which I got from the same Humble Bundle, was more enjoyable than this, and it's arguably much simpler overall. The game is silly (I wasn't /cringing/, but I never actually laughed either, and there were plenty of jokes in even just the tutorial), but that does not nearly make up for its shortcomings when it comes down to actually /playing/ it.

I have no problem with a game pushing the traditional boundaries of its genre, but it has to be in a way that /improves/ the experience, otherwise it just feels like the game is missing things. And that's how I felt the whole time I played.

I know my total playtime isn't very long, but my problems are all with the core mechanics, which are present from the first minute, so I don't think this was hasty.

The more you love roguelikes, the less I recommend this game for you. It's a decent My First Roguelike for those uninitiated into the genre, but that's about it.

reviewText:
Call it a player experience in extremely bad luck, but ultimately, I feel that the time I've invested into Dungeons of Dremor has been an utter waste.

Having raised three characters, and having every single character's life end with random abrupt inescapable and arguably unfair situations has really soured me on the game. Just be aware before going in that when things go wrong in this game, it'll in all likelihood be unfair (swarmed by enemies out of thin air, overleveled enemies just randomly appearing and one shotting you, etc) and ruin any amount of fun you've had prior to that character's untimely demise.

That said, Dredmor is an approachable roguelike that handles its systems nicely. It can seem overwhelming at first, but when boiled down, all those skills, items, and crafting come into play, there's nothing complicated about it at all. I just really can't recommend it myself given how abrupt and unfair every play through I've had has gone.

reviewText:
This game is incredibly fun to play.  It takes retro gameplay, great music, silly humor, and RPG elements, throws them into a rogue-like and calls it a day.  Dungeons of Dredmor feels, plays, and bleeds retro but still manages to be a new, unique experience.

The combat system is what you'd expect from a rogue-like of the sort.  Melee weapons stab or bash at close range while magic and crossbows deal with enemies farther away.  You click, you (may) hit, rinse and repeat.  While that sounds boring, the game does a great job at giving players variety (especially with magic!)

Another major reason that I love this game is the skills.  The skills and attached skill trees (more like a 'line') are in depth and compare to that of modern day triple A RPGs.  You can be anything you want
date: leading to rediculous (and awesome) combinations. You want to be a sword-wielding
hoursPlayed: blood magic casting
voteText: vampire with a hobby in blacksmiting?  DoD lets you do just that.\n\nIn general
helpfulPercent: this game makes the genre more accessible as ever because it's 3 different difficulty levels cater to the casual as well as the rogue-like veteran.  Ive played most of the recent rogue-likes that have come out and enjoyed them all but DoD takes the cake.  It is insanely fun and super addicting and I highly recommend this game."

reviewText: This was the first rogue-like game I ever played, and at the time I didn't even know what rogue-like meant. I just saw this game as a dungeon crawler where the dungeon changes every time you play. Endless replayability, heck yeah! This game was easy to learn how to play, but my goodness is it hard to master. I've spent many an hour on this game and so far, I haven't beaten it once. came close once, but otherwise I'm lucky if I make it past the 5th floor. I keep coming back to it again and again, with the hopes of someday beating it at least once. Also, there's lot's of quirky and hilarious dialogue which makes the game even more fun to play. I'd recommend this to any fan of rogue-like games, especially for the very low price tag, and I also recommend it for those who are new to the genre or who like dungeon crawling/hack-and-slash games.

reviewText:
Absolutely one of the best roguelikes of our time, Dungeons of Dredmor is a turn based dungeon crawler with enough humor and videogame/internet references to make the most jaded gamer crack a smile and enough difficulty to bring back the long missed feelings of gnashing teeth and yanked hair after your 12th permadeath gameover. reviewText: Although I'm assuming I haven't clocked up anywhere near enough hours to provide a proper overview of all of DoD's features, I cannot recommend it enough; this charming roguelike has a fantastic sense of humour and plays with all the features you'd expevt from the genre, and the gameplay of trawling procedurally generated dungeon floors in the pursuit of murdering Lord Dredmor himself is disgustingly addictive, drawing you in to hours of starting and re-starting as you learn the mechanics from the multiples of skills you can pick from to aid your adventure. These range from simple weapon mastery trees to ludicrous skills like 'Emomancy' granting you powers to manipulate and utilise the energy of angst and deprivation, or the 'Archaeology' tree which grants a certain iconic fedora and bonuses to trap avoidance and general nimbleness.\nOverall, Dungeons of Dredmor is a great whole package at £4.99 for all the DLC and the base game, and promises to draw both old-school roguelike fans and newbs to the genre alike by adding actual graphics whilst sticking to the core mechanics of loot hoarding, character progression and permadeath.

reviewText:
THE GOOD:

This game is incredible. It's similar to Pixel Dungeon, but deeper and more difficult (as there are many paths to ultimate victory). I've been playing it on easy and medium levels and the difficulty ramps up in jumps, but each time I experiment with builds I get closer to success.

I've still not completed the game, but, with 45 hours on record, I'm still up for the challenge, and always happy to thrash on monsters.

Finally, I must say: the support at Gaslight Games has been INCREDIBLE. I've yet to close the loop with them and report my experience, but they helped get me up and running with the game on Steam.

THE NOT-ALL-GOOD:
Your character's art doesn't change to reflect your items. BUT, this chews through art budgets very quickly. So, frankly, it's really a non-issue. I'm pleased the development and art efforts went where they did.

reviewText:
Rating: 8/10

Dungeons of Dredmor is a mix between the ASCII game Nethack and the card game Muchkin. It's a really fun rogue-like and offers hours of entertainment. If you like roguelikes, then the $5 price is a steal. There really isn't a class sytem - you can choose whichever skills you want to start off with. This means that you can have entirely different combat experiences depending on which skills you choose.

For it's cheap cost, hours of fun, and being true to roguelikes, I rate this game a solid 8/10.

reviewText:
Rating: 8/10

Dungeons of Dredmor is a mix between the ASCII game Nethack and the card game Muchkin. It's a really fun rogue-like and offers hours of entertainment. If you like roguelikes, then the $5 price is a steal. There really isn't a class sytem - you can choose whichever skills you want to start off with. This means that you can have entirely different combat experiences depending on which skills you choose.

For it's cheap cost, hours of fun, and being true to roguelikes, I rate this game a solid 8/10.

Hero's Log, sometime after I painfully learned that demons are just as powerful as it first seems...

I obtained a rare artifact today. A strange box that transformed whatever I put inside it into Lutefisk. Fascinating. Sometime later, it occured to me that I might be able to rid myself of this box by turning it into lutefisk with it's own properties.

Unfortunately, upon putting the box inside itself, I inadvertantly caused an arcane singularity, and was killed by an all-consuming magical fire.

10/10, would serve the Lutefisk God again. Skol!

reviewText:
A very fun and quite humorous send-up of classic roguelikes.

It adds a lot of neat and fun mechanics to the formula. The skill pool is huge and goes from down-to-earth skills such as smithing and swords to the more far-out skills such as Mathemagics and Emomancy. Finding the synergies between skills as you fine-tune your build is immensely satisfying.

If you're a fan of old-school dungeon crawlers and roguelikes, you should definitely give Dungeons of Dremor a look.

reviewText: I am a fan of NetHack, so when I found a more modern game in the roguelike genre that doesnt stray too far from traditional, i had to play it. If you have never played a roguelike before, keep in mind that you WILL die.. over and over. The goal is just to keep trying to get a bit further each time, and if that fails, hope you die in an interesting way. Instead of being tied to a class, you pick from a selection of physical, magical, and crafting skills. The dungeons are randomly generated each time, so you never know what you are going to find. I highly reccomend this one as an introduction into roguelikes, for anyone who doesnt know about them, and to those who love the genre, Why dont you have this already? Its pretty cheap too, which is always a plus
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
What can I say about Dungeons of Dredmor? Well, for one, it's one of my favorite games on Steam. I could spend countless hours playing character after character looting and exploring dungeon after dungeon, and never have the same experuience twice. I'm not kidding. Not even once have I found a room exactly the same. Talk about Procedurally Generated.

The joy of this game does not come in any one category. There are parts of this game that, if anywhere else, would make for a horrid experience. The combat isn't that complicated, but it can be difficult, and it's always fun. Wearing a piece of clothing or weilding a specfic weapon doesn't effect your outward appearance, only adding (or subtracting) from your stats, so for people who like to see your appearance change it's a problem.

Dungeons of Dredmor isn't like most other games out there, as you may have already guessed, but it is ery entertaining, and hours will go by without you even knowing it. There is so much content in this game, and of all the hours I have played so far, I have not made it past the second dungeon. Is this because it is difficult? Maybe a little. But the real reason is that the game is really really big. Too many different types of monsters to count, as many weapons, more items than I've ever seen in a game, and interesting text on everything.

This game has a lot of pop culture references and stuff like that, so for people who hate that with a passion, this game probably isn't a good choice for you. But if you want a game that can make you laugh, that's really fun, and can let you waste away hours of your life, then this game is perfect for you.

I highly reccomend this game.

reviewText:
In short, great game. This is one of the most dungeon-crawlery dungeon-crawlers I've ever played and I love it.

At this point I just roll through purely on damage and buffs (smart choices, I went nearly full rogue with a bit of warrior mixed in); I should probably learn what potions do at some point. Smithing doesn't interest me, nor does alchemy or magic, but I'm sure it's a staple for some.

The only thing I don't like is backtracking, but, hey. It's a dungeon crawler.

All around great game. If you love RPGs with menus on menus and a decent learning curve, I'd definitely get this. It's addicting as hell and I've only scratched the surface of a much broader game.

reviewText:
I played this game a lot on my old 2008 year old low budget laptop on Linux. I like it when you don't need a beefy computer in order to play some good game.

At first I was confused by the interface: lots of different items, not very convenient crafting interface, lots of numbers and secondary stats on character screen scared me. But with little time and patience I figured all that out. So I definitely recommend this game. It has good sense of humor and provides certain challenge. Just try not to get discouraged if you die a few times. :-)

The only minor drawback is that it gets repetitive after some time, especially if you chose big rooms and if you are playing with mods, which provide more levels. But I guess you can say that for any game. :-)

reviewText:
THE GOOD:

This game is incredible. It's similar to Pixel Dungeon, but deeper and more difficult (as there are many paths to ultimate victory). I've been playing it on easy and medium levels and the difficulty ramps up in jumps, but each time I experiment with builds I get closer to success.

I've still not completed the game, but, with 45 hours on record, I'm still up for the challenge, and always happy to thrash on monsters.

Finally, I must say: the support at Gaslight Games has been INCREDIBLE. I've yet to close the loop with them and report my experience, but they helped get me up and running with the game on Steam.

THE NOT-ALL-GOOD:
Your character's art doesn't change to reflect your items. BUT, this chews through art budgets very quickly. So, frankly, it's really a non-issue. I'm pleased the development and art efforts went where they did.

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Dungeons of Dredmor is a great roguelike game in the spirit of the original games. Turn based, dungeon crawl with challenges of inventory management (though a bit easier now).

The challenge starts at the very beginning with the selection of a skill set that has the proper synergy (ghads, I actually wrote that? No, I'm not a middle manager, why do you ask) - though do give random a try (there's a badge for it). Tossed into this mix is crafting (and encrusting), spell and ammunition management, and choices about which skills to level up when.

The theme game is to be taken light heartedly, but the challenge of the game is right up there with Nethack and its brethren (and yet, it is still much more approachable than the roguelikes of old). You will find new and interesting ways to die (there's a badge for that too). The game is a worth it at twice its standard price

reviewText: I normally dislike rogue-likes and turn-based games. No, I take that back. I normally -loathe- them. However, there's something about Dungeons of Dredmor that I really, really like. Maybe it's the silly humor, numerous pop culture references, and and at times dry wit. Maybe it's the gameplay. I felt both engaged but at the same time I could quit at any time and come back to it later. Heck, even playing with permadeath on and on the hardest difficulty is fun because it's hilarious to see how exactly you'll die and how long it'll take (spoiler: some of the achievements give it away).\n\nLike my buddy Graham said when he recommended this game, give a try even if you're someone like me, someone whose attention span is ill-suited for rogue-likes and/or turn-based games. It's cheap (especially when it's on sale) and for the price it's a lot of fun that I know I'll be coming back to in the future.

reviewText: This is an awesome RPG with hilarious skills, enemies, and items.  I really enjoy trying out every skill tree to figure out the best build - and after 70 hours of gameplay I have only once gotten to the 9th floor (there are 10 or 15, depending on whether you activate the DLC).  The game gets more and more punishing as you progress, and there is less room for mistakes (PERMADEATH ALL THE WAY!). It is very easy to die from a stupid mistake! Levels are randomly generated so each playthrough is different.   Very addicting - I haven't played so much of one game for quite a while.

reviewText: My initial look at the video and screenshots did not give me high expectations for this game.  Fortunately, I still decided to try it out, and I am very glad I did.  This is an excellent and charming rogue-like, very true to the spirit of the original rogue, or later, nethack.  The graphics and sound effects are not mindblowing, but they work very well.\n\nIf I were to criticize at all, it would be just to wish for some more UI options, such as moving/adjusting the log scroller, and perhaps adding more detail to it, as well as some way to look at tiles that are behind walls.  But these are minor annoyances, and don't really detract from the fun I've had playing so far.  I would recommend this to anyone who enjoys rogue-likes in a heartbeat!

reviewText: This is hands-down my favorite rogue-like (an actual rogue-like) that I've ever played. The base game itself contains so many ridiculous skill trees and items that its hard not to derive even a little fun from it even for those not into turn based RPG's. On top of that the DLC's add even more content that adds to the absurdity and wonder of this game and one of them is free. Also, this game is cheap as hell. It is easily worth triple what they are charging for it and I honestly feel kinda bad that I can't hand them more money. In addition, just in case you manage to somehow-inconceivabley-run out of things to do in the base game and DLC, the mod support for this game is fantastic, with hundreds of new skills, items, and enemies to be easily downloaded from the workshop. This game easily falls onto my list of must own games on Steam and for this price ($5) there is no reason not to own this game.

reviewText:
Roguelikes in the 21st century should be like this. Graphical, yet simplistic. Deep, yet won't take ages to learn. Mind you, Dungeons of Dredmor is by no means easy.

You are a Hero, chosen to vanquish the evil lord Dredmor. In order to reach him, you must use your wits and skills (chosen in sets of seven during character creation, out of several dozens of skill sets) and reach the tenth level of the dungeon before meeting with the dread lord. (for your reference, I have not ventured deeper than level six, and this was with a character with some 10+ hours of playtime.)

And then there are the achievements for you to accomplish. Some are ridiciously easy (like killing some Diggles, oh you will meet them, lots of them in your journeys) and some are rather difficult (especially some skill trees are quite difficult to master, not to mention completing the game with the hardest difficulty setting and permadeath... *shiver*)

A very good game that ought to keep you occupied for quite a time.

reviewText: Interested in classic-style roguelikes, but intimidated by the harsh learning curve? Worry not! Dungeons of Deadmor is very accessible, with tutorials and helpful tooltips to keep you informed and make sure you know that it really is your own fault every time you die, because for all of the steps Dredmore makes to keep the game accessible, it retains the kind of punishing difficulty that roguelikes are famous for. A wonderful sense of humor and one of the more interesting skill and leveling systems I've seen in an RPG make this one a keeper.
